sample.title: Metaâ€™s $2 Billion Bet To Win Over Enterprise Customers
sample.description:
In its latest aggressive AI move, Meta has acquired the intelligent agent firm Manus for $2 billion. The deal underscores Metaâ€™s pursuit of enterprise dominance as the company faces mounting pressure to justify its massive AI infrastructure costs. However, the acquisition has sparked immediate backlash, with long-time Manus users retreating from the platform following the announcement. CNBCâ€™s Julia Boorstin explores the high-stakes implications for Mark Zuckerberg as he warns investors that 2026 will see a significant surge in capital expenditures.

Reporting by: Julia Boorstin, Stephen Desaulniers

sample.title: Why Tariff Refunds Might Not Lower Prices
sample.description:
If the Supreme Court rules the tariffs are illegal, the refund process could become a lengthy back-and-forth between courts. Meanwhile, consumers are unlikely to see price drops as businesses deal with cash flow crunches. CNBC's Lori Ann LaRocco breaks down the three likeliest scenarios and why businesses will still be left waiting for their money.

sample.description:
Daniela and Dario Amodei left OpenAI five years ago to form Anthropic.

Anthropicâ€™s revenue has grown 10x annually for three straight years, with 85% coming from business customers â€” the inverse of OpenAIâ€™s consumer-heavy model.

sample.description:

sample.title: Who could replace Jamie Dimon as CEO of JPM?
sample.description:
JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon has for years maintained that his retirement was perpetually 5 years away. In 2024, for the first time, he acknowledged that window was shrinking.

That makes the inevitable questions surrounding Dimonâ€™s tenure loom large as he approaches 70 years of age. Will JPMorganâ€™s era of dominance be over when Dimon exits as CEO?

sample.title: Do heat pumps make your bills cheaper? #UK #Energy #HeatPump #GreenTech #BBCNews
What is Trump's Board of Peace? | Global News Podcast
sample.description:
When the White House announced the creation of a new international body, it was framed as part of the Gaza peace plan. 

But US President Donald Trump appears to have much more wide-reaching ambitions for his Board of Peace. A leaked draft of the charter suggests it will have a broader purpose of resolving global conflicts. 

Many countries and world leaders have been invited to join, including China and Russia.

Is this a new international body designed to challenge or replace the United Nations? And what power would it have?
 
Subscribe to the Global News Podcast wherever you get your podcasts or find more episodes here: https://bbc.in/GlobalNewsPodcast

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

sample.title: Donald Trump drops threat of tariffs over Greenland after Nato talks in Davos | BBC News
sample.description:
US President Donald Trump has said he is dropping plans to add a 10% tariff to goods from eight European countries over their opposition to his push to acquire Greenland.
 
In a post on social media Trump said he has "formed the framework of a future deal with respect to Greenland" after talks with Nato's secretary general.
 
Earlier, the president ruled out using force to take over Greenland - but said he was seeking "immediate negations" to acquire the island.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#DonaldTrump #Greenland #BBCNews

Donald Trump presents Europe a dilemma on Greenland | BBC News
sample.description:
The US's Nato allies in Europe are facing a difficult and dangerous dilemma when it comes to how to respond to Donald Trumpâ€™s determination to acquire Greenland, the BBC's Security Correspondent Frank Gardner says.
 
The Foreign Ministers of Denmark and Greenland returned empty-handed from talks in Washington.
 
So now thereâ€™s talk of the need to get tough with Trump, with French President Macron and German Chancellor Merz mooting, albeit reluctantly, the possibility of reciprocal trade sanctions on US imports.
 
But while this may just conceivably achieve a US climbdown, it is also playing with fire.
